--- title: "Filter on conditions for more than one variable at the time" date: "2022-03-21" category: til --- TIL I learned that you can filter on conditions for more than one variable at a time using `if_any()` or `if_all()`.

Just to add to the confusion (üòÖ) I think you still do use it for mutate but not for filter?

‚ö†Ô∏è Using `across()` in `filter()` is deprecated, use `if_any()` or `if_all()`.

— Lucy D‚ÄôAgostino McGowan (@LucyStats) March 21, 2022
Turns out that `across()` is only for selecting functions (like `summarize()` and `mutate()`). This was announced in [dplyr 1.0.4](https://www.tidyverse.org/blog/2021/02/dplyr-1-0-4-if-any/). You use `if_any()` vs. `if_all()` depending if you need to match some vs. all columns. `if_any()`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mtcars %>% as_tibble() %>% mutate(across(everything(), as.integer)) %>% filter(if_any(contains("m"), ~ . == 0)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 19 √ó 11 mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb 1 21 6 258 110 3 3 19 1 0 3 1 2 18 8 360 175 3 3 17 0 0 3 2 3 18 6 225 105 2 3 20 1 0 3 1 4 14 8 360 245 3 3 15 0 0 3 4 5 24 4 146 62 3 3 20 1 0 4 2 6 22 4 140 95 3 3 22 1 0 4 2 7 19 6 167 123 3 3 18 1 0 4 4 8 17 6 167 123 3 3 18 1 0 4 4 9 16 8 275 180 3 4 17 0 0 3 3 10 17 8 275 180 3 3 17 0 0 3 3 11 15 8 275 180 3 3 18 0 0 3 3 12 10 8 472 205 2 5 17 0 0 3 4 13 10 8 460 215 3 5 17 0 0 3 4 14 14 8 440 230 3 5 17 0 0 3 4 15 21 4 120 97 3 2 20 1 0 3 1 16 15 8 318 150 2 3 16 0 0 3 2 17 15 8 304 150 3 3 17 0 0 3 2 18 13 8 350 245 3 3 15 0 0 3 4 19 19 8 400 175 3 3 17 0 0 3 2 ``` ::: ::: `if_all()`: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} mtcars %>% as_tibble() %>% mutate(across(everything(), as.integer)) %>% filter(if_all(contains("am"), ~ . == 0)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` # A tibble: 19 √ó 11 mpg cyl disp hp drat wt qsec vs am gear carb 1 21 6 258 110 3 3 19 1 0 3 1 2 18 8 360 175 3 3 17 0 0 3 2 3 18 6 225 105 2 3 20 1 0 3 1 4 14 8 360 245 3 3 15 0 0 3 4 5 24 4 146 62 3 3 20 1 0 4 2 6 22 4 140 95 3 3 22 1 0 4 2 7 19 6 167 123 3 3 18 1 0 4 4 8 17 6 167 123 3 3 18 1 0 4 4 9 16 8 275 180 3 4 17 0 0 3 3 10 17 8 275 180 3 3 17 0 0 3 3 11 15 8 275 180 3 3 18 0 0 3 3 12 10 8 472 205 2 5 17 0 0 3 4 13 10 8 460 215 3 5 17 0 0 3 4 14 14 8 440 230 3 5 17 0 0 3 4 15 21 4 120 97 3 2 20 1 0 3 1 16 15 8 318 150 2 3 16 0 0 3 2 17 15 8 304 150 3 3 17 0 0 3 2 18 13 8 350 245 3 3 15 0 0 3 4 19 19 8 400 175 3 3 17 0 0 3 2 ``` ::: ::: Any tidyselect usage is allowable inside `if_*()` just like inside `across()`, so they work very similarly. **Thanks to [@gvelasq](https://github.com/gvelasq) for his explanation.**
